To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

22 Junij
1591
. M
r
Bodeley to my L./

May it please yo
r
good L. the 13 of this moneth
I advertised yo
r
L. of my being at
Dorkum,
w
t
e
Councel of state
, from whens we tooke o
r
jorney towardes
e army. But before we came
thither we had worde from
e
Count,
at the Ene-
mie at
Groeninghen
had opened certaine sluces,
whereby of six partes about
e towne, there were
five overflowen, and
e army on
e soddaine
forced to dislodge. The possibilitie to lette in
e water was nether knowen to
Count William,
nor to
e Deputies of
Friseland,
on whome
e army
depended for good direction in
e siege. For
they were all persuaded, that
e water of those
sluces could not hinder o
r
approaches, nor the
planting of
e artillerie. But sins it fell out
otherwise, it was thought convenient, that o
r
forces should presently marche towardes
Delfzil
w
ch
is a strong fort upon
e Ems distant
from Groeninghen North Est 3 long dutche
miles. The taking of this fort, because it
serveth as a haven to Groeninghen, was ge-
nerally thought of singular importance.
There was order also taken,
at
e artillerie
w
ch
was not yet disbarked, but only kept in
a readines in
e shippes before Groeninghen,
should be brought to Delfzil by water. Upon
this resolution
e Councel of state finding no
securitie for them selves to goe to Delfzil by
water
land
, when
e troupes were departed, went
thither by shippe. Presently upon o
r
co
m
ing
e approches were made, and as yesternight
e artillerie made ready to be planted.
Wherupon
e Enemie w
t
in, albeit for
e space
fol.158v
of three daies he had shotte upon us very hotly
upon
e first summoning condescended to a
parley, and surrendred presently upon like
composition as those of
Zutphen
and
Deventer.
Their want w
t
in was both of men and powder,
and no kinde of hope to be relieved by
e Spa-
niard. Groeninghen excepted, there
are only nowe remaining in
e territorie of
Groeninghen the fortes of
Upslacke
and
Em-
mentill
, w
ch
are fortes of some strength, lieng
Southwest from Groeninghen, w
t
in two or three
leagues, but unable to w
t
stand any forceable
batterie. For w
ch
is it resolved,
at they shall
be summoned out of hand. And as for those
of Groeninghen, it is first intended, for
at
nowe it is thought they will harcken to reason,
that they shall be moved by faire offers, to
unite themselves to
e other Provinces, w
ch
if
they chance to reject, as most men thinke
they will, reposing no confidence in any pro-
mise of
e states, then they doe determine,
as I am told underhand (for as yet of
themselves they doe not signifie so unto me)
to use her
Ma
ties
countenance by my meanes
to
e effect of that Commission, w
ch
was
graunted unto me above twelve moneth
agoe. For mine owne part, because it is
a mater that doth touche themselves, and
because I knowe it is their humo
r
, not to
use her Ma
tie
but as a refuge in extremitie,
I doe not deale by persuasion ether one way
or other. For if they can not speede of them-
selves, they will come very willingly to crave
fol.159r
her Hig
nes
assistance: and otherwise for me to
move them therunto, considering howe sleightly
they regarded it before, I knowe not howe it
would stand w
t
e hono
r
of her Ma
tie
. Howbeit
I doe see aswell by this, as by many other their
proceedinges,
at whosoever will not beare w
t
their diffidence and jalousie, and other natural
imperfections, but exact more precisely an hono-
rable cariage in their dealing, then
e advance-
ment of an action, shall but hinder that in
e end, w
ch
might be otherwise effected, and do
her Ma
tie
in this contrey very litle good ser-
vice. We have certaine informac
o
n
both by letters intercepted, and by other good
intelligence, that
e
Duke of Parma
is lodged
in a cloister called
Marienboom,
adjoining to
the fort of
Rees,
very muche distressed, for
lacke of victuals and cariage: so as nowe
we are persuaded, that his jorney is wholy
staied, for troubling these quarters. Besides
his nombers to
e uttermost are not thought
to exceed 6000 foote, and 150 horse, w
ch
are
also in dissension, and in very great
[mi]
serie
for many great wantes. In effect, for my
self, I did never yet perceave,
at ether
e
Enemie in these contreis was ever so perplexed,
or so likely in all places to be dishonored in
his actions, as he is at this present.
And thus
I take my humble leave. At
e campe
before Delfzil, where we make o
r
entrie
this morning. June 22 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
